a.g: The revelation of the Book is from Allah, the Exalted in Might, the Knowing.
The forgiver of sin, acceptor of repentance, severe in punishment, owner of abundance. There is no deity except Him; to Him is the destination.
No one disputes concerning the signs of Allah except those who disbelieve, so be not deceived by their [uninhibited] movement throughout the land.

The people of Noah denied before them and the [disbelieving] factions after them, and every nation intended [a plot] for their messenger to seize him, and they disputed by [using] falsehood to [attempt to] invalidate thereby the truth. So I seized them, and how [terrible] was My penalty.

Those [angels] who carry the Throne and those around it exalt [Allah] with praise of their Lord and believe in Him and ask forgiveness for those who have believed, [saying], "Our Lord, You have encompassed all things in mercy and knowledge, so forgive those who have repented and followed Your way and protect them from the punishment of Hellfire.

Indeed, those who disbelieve will be addressed, "The hatred of Allah for you was [even] greater than your hatred of yourselves [this Day in Hell] when you were invited to faith, but you refused."

Indeed, He, the Exalted, says: "He casts the spirit [al-ruh] from His command upon whom He wills of His servants." And He attributed misguidance to Iblis, for He, the Exalted, says: "To lead astray from His path." And misguidance [al-ighwa'] is the halting of the servants short of reaching the ultimate purpose of wisdom. So see how He ascribed it to the servant upon whom He is wrathful. And guidance [al-irshad] is their being conveyed to the ultimate purpose. So see how He ascribed it to the servant whom He loves. And you have in custom an example for it: If a king is in need of one to give him drink, and one to perform cupping for him and to clean the courtyard of his house from filth, and he has two servants, he does not appoint for the cupping and the cleaning except the most vile and base of them, and he does not entrust the carrying of the drink and the perfume except to the best, most complete, and most beloved of them to him. And it is not fitting for you to say, "This is my action," and was his action not without my action? For you have erred when you ascribed that to yourself. Rather, it is He who directed your motive [da'iyatika] to specify the disliked action with the disliked person and the beloved action with the beloved person, in completion of justice [al-'adl]. For His justice is at times completed by matters in which you have no part, and at times it is completed in you. For you, too, are from His actions. So your motive, your power [qudratika], your knowledge ['ilmuka], your action ['amaluka], and all the causes of your movements in expression are His action, which He arranged with justice, an arrangement from which balanced actions proceed. Except that you see only yourself, so you imagine that what appears upon you in the world of witnessing ['alam al-shahadah] has no cause from the world of the unseen and the dominion ['alam al-ghayb wa al-malakut]. It is for that reason you ascribe it to yourself.
